Hello James, 

Thank you for your reply. 

Data that you see in the results table - is the data that is stored in the Netwrix Enterprise Auditor database.
If the lowest number of days is 61 - this means that the database does not have information about users who have 30 days since last logon, there are simply no such users who's "days since last logon" are less than 61. 

This is why you do not see any entries when configuring filtering by placing 30 in "days since last logon" - the report filtering works as expected, there is no entries because there is no data that fits this filter criteria. 

Regarding the Active Directory data collection - there are no criteria for the AD data collection job to return specific "days since last logon" users.
Active Directory job solution is processing information that was collected from your active directory.
If within your active directory there are no such users who's "days since last logon" do not match 30 days or less, then you won`t see such information in the results table or the report. 

If you are sure that you have users in Active Directory for whom this attribute is less than 60 or 30 days, but you do not see this information in the report - then you need to schedule and run the following Job solutions one after another to update information in Netwrix Enterprise Auditor database:

.Active Directory Inventory 
Active Directory 

Please note, that ".Active Directory Inventory" is the primary source of AD information for the "Active Directory" solution.
As such, ".Active Directory Inventory" must be running regularly and it must be run first before running "Active Directory" job solution.

TextBody:
Hello James, 

I have an update for you.

Upon inspecting the "Active Directory" solution > "2.Users" job group> "AD_StaleUsers" job > "User Details" analysis SQL query I found that it is joining information from these two tables:
ADInventory_UsersView (Created by "1-AD_Scan" job)
ADInventory_ExceptionsView (Created by "3-AD_Exceptions" job)

As such, I went to check the 3-AD_Exceptions job that creates ADInventory_ExceptionsView table. 
I found that ADInventory_ExceptionsView table is generated based on several analysis tasks, one of which is called "Stale Users".
This is the source of the 60 days criteria as this analysis task`s query finds stale users based on parameter @STALE_THRESHOLD. 

By leveraging "Stale Users" task, the "3-AD_Exceptions" job puts users whom last logon was more than 60 days (by default) into the ADInventory_ExceptionsView table. 
These users are then cross checked with the ADInventory_UsersView (Created by "1-AD_Scan" job) table.

To summarize, in order to change criteria for the data that gets written to the "AD_StaleUsers" job report, perform these steps:

1. Navigate to ".Active Directory Inventory" solution > "3-AD_Exceptions" job > "Analysis" > select "Stale Users" analysis. 

2. Select "Analysis Configuration" 

3. Scroll the variables list until you find @STALE_THRESHOLD

4. Change the value from 60 to 30 - this will make "3-AD_Exceptions" job treat users who haven`t logged on for more than or equal to 30 days as stale users (instead of default 60 days). 

5. Let the ".Active Directory Inventory" and "Active Directory" solutions run and complete.
Afterward, inspect the "AD_StaleUsers" job report and let me know the results. 

I will send feedback to our technical writers so that this information is added to "AD_StaleUsers" job article so that it mentions where the Stale Users threshold can be modified. 

I am looking forward hearing back from you.

Hello James, 

Thank you for your reply. 

Data that you see in the results table - is the data that is stored in the Netwrix Enterprise Auditor database.
If the lowest number of days is 61 - this means that the database does not have information about users who have 30 days since last logon, there are simply no such users who's "days since last logon" are less than 61. 

This is why you do not see any entries when configuring filtering by placing 30 in "days since last logon" - the report filtering works as expected, there is no entries because there is no data that fits this filter criteria. 

Regarding the Active Directory data collection - there are no criteria for the AD data collection job to return specific "days since last logon" users.
Active Directory job solution is processing information that was collected from your active directory.
If within your active directory there are no such users who's "days since last logon" do not match 30 days or less, then you won`t see such information in the results table or the report. 

If you are sure that you have users in Active Directory for whom this attribute is less than 60 or 30 days, but you do not see this information in the report - then you need to schedule and run the following Job solutions one after another to update information in Netwrix Enterprise Auditor database:

.Active Directory Inventory 
Active Directory 

Please note, that ".Active Directory Inventory" is the primary source of AD information for the "Active Directory" solution.
As such, ".Active Directory Inventory" must be running regularly and it must be run first before running "Active Directory" job solution.

Hello James,

Thank you for your reply.

Data that you see in the results table - is the data that is stored in the Netwrix Enterprise Auditor database.
If the lowest number of days is 61 - this means that the database does not have information about users who have 30 days since last logon, there are simply no such users who's "days since last logon" are less than 61.

This is why you do not see any entries when configuring filtering by placing 30 in "days since last logon" - the report filtering works as expected, there is no entries because there is no data that fits this filter criteria.

Regarding the Active Directory data collection - there are no criteria for the AD data collection job to return specific "days since last logon" users.
Active Directory job solution is processing information that was collected from your active directory.
If within your active directory there are no such users who's "days since last logon" do not match 30 days or less, then you won`t see such information in the results table or the report.

If you are sure that you have users in Active Directory for whom this attribute is less than 60 or 30 days, but you do not see this information in the report - then you need to schedule and run the following Job solutions one after another to update information in Netwrix Enterprise Auditor database:

.Active Directory Inventory
Active Directory

Please note, that ".Active Directory Inventory" is the primary source of AD information for the "Active Directory" solution.
As such, ".Active Directory Inventory" must be running regularly and it must be run first before running "Active Directory" job solution.
